Posts.Content: gps wrote: My mother was diagnosed with metastatic spinal cord compression in mid septmeber 2011. After the cord decompression surgery, she is on letrzole + zoledronate as she is ER+. She also underwent radiation therapy for a part in the spine [D3]. At that time, bone scans had revealed extensive skeletal mets The oncologist asked us to follow-up after 3 months. Question : What should I expect in this visit? I assume he will test the efficacy of the hormone therapy. I suppose they will do bone scans or spine MRI [it was the spine MRI that revealed the problem in September] In your follow-up visits, does your oncologist run tests to see if it is spreading to other areas like lung, liver etc? Do they do any biopsies as well? [As the receptor status can change over time] Typically, how frequently do people meet their oncologist? Thanks. PS: To moderators: Not sure whether I had to post this in the hormone therapy forum or in the metastatic forum. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2011 06:52AM gps wrote: Hi Mary,  even my mom was complaining of feeling tired/irritable for the past few months before being diagnosed with stage 4 - metastases to the bone  from what i understand these mets can increase bone destruction activity leading to more calcium in blood stream - which in turn causes tiredness etc   i found this link to be useful in explaining the above http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertreatment/Treatmenttypes/Supportivetherapies/Bisphosphonates/Zoledronicacid.aspx Best Wishes

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2011 09:41AM gps wrote: Hello, Sorry to hear about your diagnosis. My mom was also diagnosed straight away with stage 4 with mets to bones (including spinal cord compression) in Sep this year. The oncologist here in India has put her on letrozole (hormone therapy). I asked him about whether we need more aggressive treatment and he referred me to the US Govt Cancer site http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/pdq/treatment/breast/healthprofessional/page7#Section_211 So, it appears that hormone therapy is the starting point as long as the metastases have not spread to liver lungs etc. Good luck.
